Type 1 diabetes is characterised by a lack of insulin secretion by the pancreas as a result of autoimmune destruction of pancreatic beta cells.

Several factors are involved in the pathophysiology:

- genetic predisposition

- environmental factors

- autoimmune processes

The following autoantibodies are used as markers of autoimmune disease:

- anti-islanding (ICA),

- anti-insulin (in children)

- anti-GAD (glutamic acid decarboxylase)

- anti-IA2 (Islet Antigen Number 2, related to a tyrosine phosphatase)

- anti-ZnT8 (β-cell zinc transporter).


Other autoimmune diseases and/or organ-specific antibodies may be associated with type 1 diabetes: thyroidopathies, slow adrenal insufficiency, gastric atrophy, coeliac disease and vitiligo.

question.title: What is the primary cause of type 1 diabetes in children and adults?
question.description: The underlying mechanism of type 1 diabetes

option_a.title: Genetic predisposition and environmental factors
option_a.description: A combination of genetic predisposition and environmental factors

option_b.title: Autoimmune processes and hormonal imbalance
option_b.description: Autoimmune destruction of pancreatic beta cells leading to hormonal imbalance

option_c.title: Infection with a virus or bacteria
option_c.description: A viral or bacterial infection triggering the autoimmune response

option_d.title: Hormonal imbalance and metabolic syndrome
option_d.description: A hormonal imbalance and metabolic syndrome causing insulin resistance
